channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Iranian News Channel Suspends 2 Executives in Sexual Harassment Case
item.description: A prominent newscaster on Iran’s state-run English-language news channel recorded an explicit conversation in which one of the men asked her for sex.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Taliban Suicide Bomber Kills at Least 3 in Northern Afghanistan
item.description: Explosives were detonated near an Afghan National Army minibus in Mazar-i-Sharif, which had until lately seemed almost immune to violence seen in other parts of Afghanistan.
item.dc:creator: DAVID JOLLY

item.title: Syrians Desperate to Escape What U.N. Calls ‘Extermination’ by Government
item.description: A new United Nations report accuses the government of President Bashar al-Assad of “inhuman actions” against Syrian civilians.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: Syrians fleeing Aleppo arrived at the Turkish border-crossing gate in northern Syria on Saturday. A United Nations report found that the Syrian government had mounted a “systematic and widespread attack” on civilians.

item.title: Ring of Elephant Poachers Broken Up by Tanzanian Authorities
item.description: An inquiry into a British pilot’s death led to nine arrests — including a conservation intelligence officer — on charges of poaching elephants for their ivory.
item.dc:creator: WILLY LOWRY
item.media:description: Elephants at Serengeti National Park in Tanzania. The elephant population in the country fell to 43,000 in June 2015 from 109,000 in 2009.

item.title: Russia Announces Surprise Military Drills in South
item.description: The Defense Ministry order put troops in the southern region on full combat readiness, a move that appeared intended to unnerve neighbors.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: Letter From Europe: French Watch U.S. Cast of Political Characters With Fascination
item.description: For all its flaws, the American system is showing itself to be lively, engaging and full of surprises — elements noticeably lacking in French politics.
item.dc:creator: CELESTINE BOHLEN
item.media:description: Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont campaigning in New Hampshire last week. In the French view, both Mr. Sanders and Donald J. Trump have succeeded in channeling the anger and frustration of young and blue-collar voters.

item.title: 2008 Mumbai Attacks Plotter Says Pakistan’s Spy Agency Played a Role
item.description: David C. Headley, a Pakistani-American who is serving a 35-year sentence in the U.S., said he met with handlers from the agency throughout the planning of the massacre.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY and HARI KUMAR
item.media:description: The Taj Mahal Palace hotel in Mumbai was ravaged by fire, gunshots and grenade explosions during the 2008 terrorist attacks.

item.title: After Taiwan Quake, Rescue Efforts Yield Some Signs of Life
item.description: The authorities said that 117 people were believed buried in the ruins of a 17-story apartment tower, and faint cries could be heard beneath the rubble.
item.dc:creator: KEITH BRADSHER
item.media:description: A survivor was removed Sunday from the ruins of an apartment building in Tainan, Taiwan, that was leveled in a quake.

item.title: Memo From China: Chinese Who Violated One-Child Policy Remain Wary of Relaxed Rules
item.description: China’s cabinet has ordered that the registration document called a hukou be available to everyone, but many fear it will be used to levy steep fines on prior offenders.
item.dc:creator: KIKI ZHAO
item.media:description: A park in Beijing. A new effort to ensure that every Chinese citizen has a household registration, or hukou, has stirred mixed feelings among parents of children born in violation of the previous one-child limit.

item.title: Facebook Loses a Battle in India Over Its Free Basics Program
item.description: India has banned free mobile programs that allow Internet access to only certain services, a strategy employed by Facebook with its Free Basics project that was called antithetical to net neutrality.
item.dc:creator: VINDU GOEL

item.title: Russia Detains 7 Suspected of Planning Terrorist Attacks
item.description: A local news report said the cell was planning simultaneous attacks on the subway systems of St. Petersburg and Yekaterinburg.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: IVAN NECHEPURENKO

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: The Zika Virus and Brazilian Women’s Right to Choose
item.description: An epidemic gives Brazil an opening to address inequality — and abortion.
item.dc:creator: DEBORA DINIZ

item.title: Step by Step on a Desperate Trek by Migrants Through Mexico
item.description: Two days with 10 men who left Central America in early November to embark on an exhausting journey, made riskier by the Mexican authorities’ crackdown on migrants.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Central American migrants headed for the United States along railroad tracks near Los Corazones in southern Mexico in early November.

item.title: How a Medical Mystery in Brazil Led Doctors to Zika
item.description: A sudden, sharp increase in babies with “no foreheads and very strange heads” was baffling doctors in Brazil. That set off a search for answers that led to a little-known pathogen, the Zika virus.
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: DONALD G. McNEIL Jr., SIMON ROMERO and SABRINA TAVERNISE
item.media:description: An Aedes aegypti female mosquito on water inside a tire at a used tire store in Villavicencio, Colombia. The mosquito carries the Zika virus, and females leave their eggs on damp surfaces.

item.title: Geneva Journal: Geneva, a City of Diplomacy, Brims With Totems of Peace and War
item.description: The site of stalled talks on the war in Syria is filled with artistic reminders of the city’s role in trying to save humanity from itself.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.media:description: The sculpture “Rebirth” was erected in 2015 at the Palais des Nations in Geneva for the 70th anniversary of the United Nations.

item.title: News Analysis: China Struggles for Balance in Response to North Korea’s Boldness
item.description: Many Chinese analysts say the government is being humiliated by North Korea’s actions, but there are no signs Beijing will turn away from its traditional ally.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ and CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: The Chinese diplomat Wu Dawei, center, with Pak Song Il, right, of the North Korean Foreign Ministry, after arriving at Pyongyang Airport last week.

item.title: Reporter's Notebook: West Bank Settlers’ Listings on Airbnb Draw Palestinian Anger
item.description: Settlers are renting homes on Airbnb, but the Palestinian Authority condemned the website for not mentioning that the settlements are considered illegal by most of the world.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:credit: Rina Castelnuovo for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Airbnb listings from the West Bank include this isolated home in Havat Gilad, an illegal outpost near Nablus.

item.title: Italian Student’s Brutal Killing May Be Issue in Egypt-U.S. Meetings
item.description: Diplomatic visits come amid pressure by Italy for Egypt to find the killers of an Italian doctoral candidate, Giulio Regeni, whose badly beaten body was found in Cairo.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH
item.media:description: Giulio Regeni in an undated photo taken from social media.

item.title: Chinese Animal Trainers Looking for Respect in the Year of the Monkey
item.description: The tradition of performing monkeys has fallen on hard times in China, but trainers hope their animal’s turn on the Chinese zodiac cycle will improve business.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Michel Martelly, Haiti’s President, Departs Without a Successor
item.description: Thirty years to the day after Haiti’s last dictator fled and the country took its first wobbly steps toward democracy, another leader stepped down Sunday without a successor to take his place.
item.dc:creator: FRANCES ROBLES
